first_section.text_2: The FAIRsharing Community Champions put their expertise into action in one of more disciplines or area of activities, according to their interest, and are credited for their contribution via visible attribution in their ORCID and FAIRsharing profiles. Their contribution to and engagement with the FAIRsharing team gives them more knowledge about the wealth of standards (terminologies, models/formats, guidelines, identifier schema), databases (repositories and knowledge bases) and policies (by institutions, funders, journals and other stakeholders) relevant to them.
first_section.text_3: Launched in the summer of 2022, and supported by the RDA FAIRsharing WG and the RDA/EOSC-Future Ambassadorship Programme, the FAIRsharing the Community Champions Programme shows the importance of cultivating and sharing the collective knowledge on standards, databases and policies to map this complex landscape that enables the FAIR Principles.

second_section.text: Our user community is diverse in breadth and scope, with a number of stakeholder groups across all areas of research and research support. In early 2022, we began with a few Early Adopters, who have contributed greatly to the initial success of the programme, and we are now up and running with an active group of champions across all research disciplines. Our full list of community curators shows the breadth and diversity of research areas within the programme.

third_section.text: The Community Champions Programme creates a collaborative environment where domain experts are selected to oversee certain areas within the FAIRsharing registry in return for a number of professional benefits.

subsections.title: Curate for your Community
subsections.content: Community Champions self-describe their area of expertise. Through their own knowledge and via engagement with the network of experts available on our Community Champions Slack channel, they manage and curate records within their domain of interest to increase coverage and improve the content of FAIRsharing records. Community Champions work in concert with our existing maintainer community, supplementing their efforts as well as suggesting new maintainers for the in-house FAIRsharing curation team to contact. Each record has over 40 different descriptors, which allows an accurate summary of each resource to be curated within FAIRsharing. Of particular importance to our records is the curation of the ecosystem of resources within any given domain. FAIRsharing allows the connections among standards, databases and policies to be richly described, creating a dynamic network of relationships that can be navigated by our users. Each champion is attributed for their curation efforts through their user profile pages, which display their curation activities.

subsections.title: Educational Material
subsections.content: FAIRsharing is committed to increasing awareness of FAIR generally and of FAIRsharing specifically. We are always adding educational content, and utilise the Community Champions programme to ensure that we are providing material that is useful for all of the communities within our stakeholder groups. Our champions are properly cited and attributed for every contribution to FAIRsharing educational material.

subsections.title: Help your Community
subsections.content: Record maintainers in FAIRsharing are experts in – and must be developers of – a particular standard, database or policy. They curate only those resources they are directly involved with. They form the core of our user community and create a network of collaboration that ensures our records are up to date, but more importantly promotes their resource to help it be more visible, more widely adopted and more cited. In contrast, Community Champions update and manage across an ecosystem of records within their domains of interest. They are able to access all records in their discipline as well as create new ones. Community champions help their own research domains by creating records and collections that aid resource discovery and gap analysis as well as identifying targeted outreach and engagement activities.

subsections.title: Attribution for you and your organisations
subsections.content: All organisations and users within FAIRsharing have their own profiles / homepages with us that describe not just their community, but also link back to all of the records that they are associated with, ensuring attribution for their efforts. Community Champions have their status and domain of expertise listed in the Awards section within their user profiles. Further, as a trusted partner with ORCID, we also push this award to each Champion’s ORCID profile. Such ORCID Service items are awarded annually, as long as the Champion is active with us for at least part of the year.

subsections.title: Engagement
subsections.content: Community Champions have their own Slack workspace to provide a space for engagement and networking with a community of like-minded people. During the course of their tenure, Community champions will be learning data curation at a resource-level of granularity, a skill that gives them knowledge not only about the landscape of standards and databases within their community, but how to accurately describe them. Finally, champions are asked for feedback on new features such as new educational material, certification schemes, and design choices, providing them with a voice in the direction of the project.

fourth_section.text: Information on joining us is available within our Community Champions documentation. We engage with communities across all of the Natural Sciences, Engineering Sciences and Humanities & Social Sciences. After expressing your interest in the programme, we'll be in touch and, if successful, we’ll get you set up with the proper roles.

sections.text: The FAIRsharing Community Champions Programme is an engaged and respectful community made up of people from all over the world. Your involvement helps us to further our mission and to create an open platform that serves a broad range of communities, from research and research support, to policymakers, funders and societies/organisations.

Naturally, this implies diversity of ideas and perspectives on often complex problems. Disagreement and healthy discussion of conflicting viewpoints is welcome: the best solutions to hard problems rarely come from a single angle. Sometimes, we have a tendency to take disagreement personally and easily drift into behaviour that ultimately degrades a community. This is particularly acute with online communication across language and cultural gaps, where many cues of human behaviour are unavailable. We are outlining here a set of principles and processes to support a healthy community in the face of these challenges.

Fundamentally, we are committed to fostering a productive, harassment-free environment for everyone. Rather than considering this code an exhaustive list of things that you can’t do, take it in the spirit it is intended - a guide to make it easier to enrich all of us and the communities in which we participate.

Importantly: as a member of our community, you are also a steward of these values. Not all problems need to be resolved via formal processes, and often a quick, friendly but clear word on an online forum or in person can help resolve a misunderstanding and de-escalate things.

However, sometimes these informal processes may be inadequate: they fail to work, there is urgency or risk to someone, nobody is intervening publicly and you don’t feel comfortable speaking in public, etc. For these or other reasons, structured follow-up may be necessary and here we provide the means for that: we welcome reports by emailing contact@fairsharing.org .

This code applies equally to current and members, in all spaces managed by FAIRsharing. This includes the mailing lists, our GitHub organisations, our Slack channel, in-person events, and any other forums created by the project team. In addition, violations of this code outside these spaces may affect a person’s ability to participate within them.

commitments.text: We strive to be a community that welcomes and supports people of all backgrounds and identities. This includes, but is not limited to, members of any race, ethnicity, culture, national origin, color, immigration status, social and economic class, educational level, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, age, physical appearance, family status, technological or professional choices, academic discipline, religion, mental ability, and physical ability.

Your work will be used by other people, and you in turn will depend on the work of others. Any decision you take will affect users and colleagues, and you should take those consequences into account when making decisions. Remember that we’re a world-wide community. You may be communicating with someone with a different primary language or cultural background.

Not all of us will agree all the time, but disagreement is no excuse for poor behaviour or poor manners. We might all experience some frustration now and then, but we cannot allow that frustration to turn into a personal attack. It’s important to remember that a community where people feel uncomfortable or threatened is not a productive one.

commitments.black_text: Be careful in the words that you choose.
commitments.text: Be kind to others. Do not insult or put down other community members. Harassment and other exclusionary behaviour are not acceptable.
Please respect that community members choose how they spend their time in the project. A thoughtful question about your expectations is preferable to demands for another person’s time.

commitments.black_text: When we disagree, try to understand why.
commitments.text: Disagreements, both social and technical, happen all the time and FAIRsharing is no exception. Try to understand where others are coming from, as seeing a question from their viewpoint may help find a new path forward. And don’t forget that it is human to err: blaming each other doesn’t get us anywhere, while we can learn from mistakes to find better solutions.

commitments.black_text: A simple apology can go a long way.
commitments.text: It can often de-escalate a situation, and telling someone that you are sorry is an act of empathy that doesn’t automatically imply an admission of guilt.

reporting.text: If you believe someone is violating the code of conduct, please report this in a timely manner. Code of conduct violations reduce the value of the community for everyone and we take them seriously.
You can file a report by emailing contact@fairsharing.org.
